Editor's choice paper Hierarchical porous organic polymer as an efficient metal-free catalyst for acetalization of carbonyl compounds with alcohols Joong-Jo Kim a Cheang-Rae Lim a Benjaram M. Reddy a b Sang-Eon Park a ⁎ a Laboratory of Nano-Green Catalysis and Nano Center for Fine Chemical Fusion Technology, Department of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Inha University, Incheon 402-751 Republic of Korea Laboratory of Nano-Green Catalysis and Nano Center for Fine Chemical Fusion Technology Department of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Inha University Incheon 402-751 Republic of Korea b Inorganic and Physical Chemistry Division, CSIR-Indian Institute of Chemical Technology, Uppal Road, Hyderabad, 500 007, India Inorganic and Physical Chemistry Division CSIR-Indian Institute of Chemical Technology Uppal Road Hyderabad 500 007 India ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract An efficient melamine-porous organic polymer (M-POP) as N-functionalized organic polymer catalyst was synthesized with melamine and terephthalaldehyde by a facile microwave-assisted method. The synthesized M-POP exhibited a high specific surface area with hierarchical pore structure of both mesoporosity and microporosity. The rich N-moieties namely, CN and NH from the melamine precursor were found to show hydrogen-bonding ability with various organic molecules such as carbonyl compounds. This was illustrated in the acetalization of aldehydes and ketones with methanol or ethylene glycol under mild conditions as a metal-free H-bonding catalyst with high product selectivity. The superior catalytic performance of M-POP was attributed to the availability of a large number of H-bonding sites both as H-donor and H-acceptor between the reactants and the catalyst. Keywords Porous organic polymer Metal-free catalyst H-bonding catalysis Acetalization of carbonyl compounds Introduction Porous organic polymers (POPs), a new class of highly cross-linked amorphous polymers possessing high specific surface area and nanopores, have emerged as versatile materials for adsorption and catalysis as a result of their high chemical, mechanical and thermal stability, tunability, facile synthesis, and low cost [1–4]. These properties are very similar to those of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) and allow them for potential applications such as gas storage, drug release, explosives detection, and catalysis [5–10]. In particular, many studies were devoted recently towards the development and utilization of nitrogen-based POPs as efficient catalysts for various reactions of commercial significance [11,12]. The POPs with high nitrogen contents in the framework possess a high potential for uptake of metal ions or for the immobilization of metal nanoparticles [12,13]. Mesoporous carbon nitride (MCN) materials, which require carburization process during the preparation, have also been investigated and applied in a variety of catalytic reactions, such as oxidation of cyclic olefins [14], Knoevenagel condensation [15], and other applications [16,17]. Generally, in the nitrogen-based polymeric materials the catalytic active site is primarily the unshared electron pair of nitrogen, which can act as Lewis base site. Since mid-1960s, the POPs have been recognized as organic species, which are capable of behaving like organic reactants under appropriate conditions and facilitate the chemical transformations of organic species [18,19]. Because of their unique properties like hydrophobicity, good mechanical, thermal and chemical stability, low cost, and low density [20], the POPs have been recognized as promising catalysts for various reactions [15,21–26]. Further, the POPs are an attractive ecofriendly metal-free catalysts owing to their metal-free characteristics such as non-corrosive property and non-toxicity [27]. In this context, the melamine-based materials have received exceptional significance because of their very rich nitrogen moiety. Also, melamine is one of the cheap and easily available molecules with abundant nitrogen moiety. Therefore, there is a lot of interest in recent years on the synthesis of melamine-based materials for various applications. For example, Tan et al. [28] reported mesoporous polymelamine–formaldehyde as an efficient catalyst for chemo-selective acetalization of aldehydes, Edwards et al. [29] described melamine–formaldehyde polymer as an efficient ligand for the Pd-catalyzed Suzuki–Miyaura coupling reaction, and Molla et al. [30] reported a mesoporous polymelamine–formaldehyde stabilized Pd nanoparticle as a proficient catalyst for the carbonylation of aryl halides with amines. We have also successfully demonstrated the catalytic application of melamine–terephthalaldehyde polymer in the epoxidation of styrene and Knoevenagel condensation reactions [21,31]. The microwave (MW) irradiation has received a tremendous interest and it has been regarded as a novel synthesis tool for making of various materials owing to numerous advantages such as homogeneous nucleation to provide smaller and uniform crystals having rather larger external surfaces, rapid decrease in the synthesis time, phase controlled synthesis, facile morphology control, greener synthesis in an energy efficient manner, and so on [32–35]. Besides these advantages, the application of MW technique for the synthesis of nanoporous materials allows relatively facile incorporation of heteroatoms into the zeolitic frameworks, more hydrophobicity, and higher thermal stability than those of hydrothermally synthesized materials. The MW synthesized porous materials were also found to show superior catalytic performance in various industrially important reactions [36,37]. The crystallization of microporous compounds under MW irradiation was developed in the 1970s, and was characterized by mild reaction conditions, low energy consumption, rapid reaction rate, small particles, and uniform particle-size distribution. We have also extensively exploited this method in the synthesis of various materials having defined porosity, mechanical strength, and very high specific surface for different applications [38–40]. Acetalization of carbonyl compounds to facilitate acetal formation from alcohol or diol has a wide range of applications in many chemical industries [41]. The carbonyl function, as present in aldehydes and ketones, is the most versatile functional group in organic synthesis. During a synthetic sequence, a carbonyl group may have to be protected against encounter by various reagents such as acidic, basic, oxidizing, and reducing agents. Acetal formation can be achieved from alcohols or diols and used as protecting group for carbonyl compounds in organic synthesis as they are stable with respect to hydrolysis by bases and many oxidizing and reducing agents [41]. Therefore, protection of carbonyl compounds by acetal formation via reaction with alcohols or diols is a common and useful technique for multistep synthesis in drug design, organic and carbohydrate chemistry, pharmaceuticals, cosmetics, and fragrances industries [42,43]. Many types of catalysts, including conventional acids, solid acids, functionalized silica, metal catalysts, small organic molecules, and natural materials (such as kaolinite clay) have been reported to catalyze the acetal protection of carbonyls [44–50]. Although acetalization has been widely reported and well investigated, it suffers from the drawbacks such as the use of corrosive acid catalysts [48], the need for an excess amount of drying agents, poor chemo-selectivity, and incompatibility with substrates containing acid-sensitive functional groups. Therefore, there is an increasing interest in developing an acetalization protocol that is mild, greener, chemo-selective, cost-effective, and atom efficient with ease of catalyst recycling and no excessive use of water scavenging reagents [47]. On those lines, the H-bonding motif catalysts have been identified as a promising option for this protocol [51]. The hydrogen bonding catalysts are often simple to make and could be synthesized in high enantiomeric purity [52]. New reactions catalyzed by H-bonding motifs have also been investigated with an increasing pace, including asymmetric variants of commonly used organic synthesis reactions, such as aldol addition, Diels-Alder cycloaddition, and Mannich reaction [53]. It is known that for H-bonding motif, the nitrogen atoms could be used as catalytic active sites, because nitrogen can form H-bond as a proton acceptor [54,55]. Kotke and Schreiner studied the acetalization reaction of carbonyl compounds with alcohols in acid-free condition over thiourea as a homogeneous catalyst [56]. The present investigation was undertaken against the aforesaid background. Herein, we report the acetalization of carbonyl compounds with alcohols under mild conditions in short reaction times by employing an efficient hierarchical pore-structured melamine-terephthalaldehyde polymer having both secondary amine (N−H) and tertiary amine (CN) moieties. These catalysts were synthesized by the application of microwave irradiation under mild conditions with an aim to achieve high catalytic activity and selectivity towards the acetalization of carbonyl compounds with alcohols. Characterization of the synthesized catalysts was achieved by various techniques, namely, BET surface area, X-ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), solid-state NMR, and other. To support the characterization and catalytic activity results, density functional theory (DFT) measurements were also undertaken. Experimental Preparation of catalysts Melamine monomer was procured from Tokyo Chemical Industry Co. Ltd., terephthalaldehyde from Merck, dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) from Sigma Aldrich, dichloromethane (DCM) and acetone from Duksan Chemicals respectively. All chemicals were guaranteed reagent grade (GR) and used without further purification. The basic melamine porous organic polymer (M-POP) synthetic procedure adopted in this study was similar to the earlier reported literature [21,57,58]. However, a significant modification was made in the synthetic procedure by adopting microwave-assisted heating which reduced the preparation time enormously and resulted in superior catalysts. In brief, 577mg (4.575mmol) melamine and 460mg (3.430mmol) terephthalaldehyde were mixed together and dissolved in 20mL of DMSO under nitrogen atmosphere. After the reagents were dissolved in DMSO clearly, the mixture solution was loaded in a Teflon coated pressure vessel for microwave irradiation (MARS-5 from CEM Co. Ltd.). The optimized microwave irradiation treatment was carried out at 160°C for 2h with 400W microwave power. The formed product was cooled to room temperature, filtered and washed with excess dichloromethane, cooled water, and acetone. The resulting product was dried under vacuum for 12h at 200°C. Characterization of M-POP X-ray diffraction pattern was obtained on a Rigaku MiniFlex X-ray diffractometer with CuKα radiation source in the 2θ range of 5–50° with a 2θ step size of 0.02° and a step time of 2.4s at ambient temperature. The as-synthesized M-POP was pretreated at 200°C for 6h before N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm measurements at liquid nitrogen temperature (−196°C) on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 instrument. The specific surface area was calculated by Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method from desorption data in the relative pressure (P/P0) range=0.040–0.25. The total pore volume was estimated from the amount of adsorbed nitrogen at the relative pressure of 0.98. The pore size distribution was calculated by applying Barret–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method from desorption branch. Infrared spectroscopy (IR) measurements were made on a Bruker VERTEX 80V FTIR unit at ambient conditions. The measured wavelength range was from 4000 to 400cm−1. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy measurements were made on a Thermo Scientific Instrument with monochromated Al Kα radiation source. The transmission electron microscope images were obtained on a JEM 2100F, JEOL instrument equipped with a slow-scan CCD camera and at an accelerating voltage of 400kV. The solid 13C CP TOSS and 15N CP-MAS nuclear magnetic resonance spectra were recorded on a Bruker Avance II solid state 500MHz spectrometer. The solid 1H MAS NMR spectra was recorded on a Digital Bruker Avance III 400MHz spectrometer. Acetalization reaction Before conducting the acetalization reaction, the M-POP catalyst was pretreated in vacuum at 200°C overnight for conditioning. All catalytic reactions were performed in the EYELA WORLD ChemiStation PPS-1511 personal organic synthesizer. All carbonyl compounds (aldehydes and ketones) with methanol or ethylene glycol were taken in 50mL Pyrex vials having magnetic stirring bar for conducting the reactions. The reactants, 1mmol with 100mmol of methanol or ethylene glycol were mixed to which a 10mg of catalyst was added and mixed thoroughly. The reaction mixtures were placed in the personal organic synthesizer system with stirring provision at 40°C for 2h. After completion of the reaction, reaction mixtures were separated from the catalysts. The separated reaction mixtures were analyzed by Agilent 7890N GC equipped with HP-5 capillary column and FID. Both injector and detector temperature were maintained at 250°C. The GC analysis program adopted was as follows: the starting temperature of 50°C was kept for 1min and then raised to 250°C at a rate of 20°Cmin−1 and maintained there for 3min. Products were identified with the help of GC–MS. DFT calculations The density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed by Material Studio 6.0 software from Accelrys. Firstly, geometry optimization was performed by Becke, three-parameter, Lee-Yang-Parr (B3LYP) functional method [59]. The B3LYP functional method includes Hartree-Fock exchange to reduce the interaction error. After each material’s structure was optimized by B3LYP functional method, the binding energy of the reagent and catalyst was calculated. For calculating H-bond binding energy, the binding energy states with and without H-bond were considered. Results and discussion Characterization of porous melamine-terephthalaldehyde polymer (M-POP) The synthetic procedure of M-POP implemented in the present investigation is schematically presented in Scheme 1 . The wide angle XRD pattern of the synthesized M-POP in the 2θ range of 5–50° is shown in Fig. 1 . As can be noted from Fig. 1, a broad peak centred at 2θ=21° confirms the formation of an amorphous polymeric network. Absence of characteristic crystalline peaks endorses that the formation of condensation polymer is complete and it is free from monomeric impurities [60,61]. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm along with the pore size distribution curve are shown in Fig. 2 . The Fig. 2 clearly reveals the presence of a hysteresis loop at the relative pressure (P/P0) of above 0.4. The adsorption-desorption isotherm and the pore size distribution analysis data suggest the existence of significant mesoporosity along with micropores [62]. The typical mesoporosity in the synthesized material is introduced due to the rapid polymerization when microwave irradiation is employed. The organic monomers play a key role in the absorption of microwave irradiation and dissipate the energy absorbed to the surroundings [34]. Water is formed as a byproduct during the polymerization of melamine and terephthalaldehyde. The H2O being highly dielectric, it continuously attempts to reorient in the electromagnetic radiation and is expected to help in the creation of mesoporosity. This was the major advantage in the application of microwave irradiation during the synthesis. From N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms, the specific surface area was calculated in the relative pressure (P/P0) range of 0.04–0.25. Thus obtained BET surface area was found to be 811m2g−1 (t-plot micro surface area=695m2g−1 and meso surface area=116m2g−1) indicating a high degree of cross linking in the M-POP which is also evident from the pore size distribution curve (Fig. 2) and TEM micrograph (Fig. S1, Supporting Information). The total pore volume was calculated from the amount of adsorbed N2 at the relative pressure of 0.99 and was found to be 0.59cm3g−1. These observations clearly signifies the importance of microwave irritation in the synthesis of M-POP in the present investigation. The FTIR spectrum of M-POP (Fig. S2, SI) confirms that the polymerization is near to perfection by the absence of (CO) stretching vibrations corresponding to the aldehyde functionality from the precursor terephthalaldehyde. The absence of bands at 3470 and 3420cm−1 (NH2 stretching) that correspond to the primary amine group of melamine also supports the polymer formation. The peaks centred at 1575, 1485, and 1375cm−1 correspond to the hetero-aromatic triazine ring. The bands at 1172 and 1025cm −1 correspond to the secondary amine polymer framework as per the literature [21]. In order to further investigate the elemental composition of nitrogen and carbon in the M-POP, the XPS analysis was carried out. Fig. 3 shows the C 1s and N 1s XP spectra of M-POP. The individual components were deconvoluted and the peak assignments were made based on their chemical shifts [58]. The C 1s XP spectrum showed the typical peaks at 284.8 and 286.9eV, and another peak at 288.2eV which can be attributed to the existence of sp2 CC owing to the aromatic terephthalaldehyde, CN of the heteroaromatic triazine ring, and CN from the secondary amine polymer framework of M-POP, respectively. The deconvoluted N 1s XP spectrum exhibited two distinct peaks at around 398.1eV which correspond to the C−NC functionality arising from the triazine ring, and another peak at 399.1eV related to sp3 CN bond [58]. In order to further evaluate the structure of M-POP, we have utilized the 13C and 15N solid state NMR spectroscopy. The solid state 13C CP TOSS NMR spectrum (Fig. S3, SI) exhibited three resonances at 167, 124, and 54ppm respectively. The 13C NMR peak at 167ppm is due to the triazine ring of M-POP, the other peak at 124ppm is related to the aromatic carbon of the terephthalaldehyde’s benzene ring, and the other peak at 54ppm is due to the carbon of secondary amine group of M-POP’s triazine ring [17,55]. The solid state 15N CP-MAS spectrum of M-POP showed two major resonances at 99 and 176ppm respectively (Fig. S4, SI). The peak at 99ppm is associated to the nitrogen in the triazine ring of M-POP, and the peak at 176ppm is due to the secondary amine. The peak at 275ppm is due to the imine peak (CNC-) that was from the melamine and terephthalaldehyde’s condensation product [21,61]. Based on the information obtained from FTIR, XPS, 13C and 15N solid-state NMR and other techniques, it can be concluded beyond doubt that there is a formation of polymeric M-POP. Acetalization of carbonyl compounds with MeOH or ethylene glycol The acetalization of carbonyl compounds with MeOH or ethylene glycol employing M-POP catalyst was carried out without the use of solvents at 40°C for different times as shown in Scheme 2 . The catalytic results pertaining to the acetalization of carbonyl compounds with MeOH are presented in Table 1 . The results pertaining to acetalization of aldehydes are listed from entry 1–6, and the acetalization of ketones are at entry 7 and 8 (Table 1). As can be noted from entry 1 and 2, the acetalization of benzaldehyde was highly effective proving the selective products within the short duration of 1h. On the other hand, as shown at entry 3 and 4 (4-methoxybenzaldehyde) and entry 5 and 6 (trans-cinnamaldehyde), the conversion of aldehydes was less at 1h reaction time and increased with increase of reaction time to 2h. As expected, the conversion of benzaldehyde was higher than the other aldehydes, because benzaldehyde is more reactive than 4-methoxybenzaldehyde and trans-cinnamaldehyde. Due to the inductive effect owing to the presence of OCH3 group in 4-methoxybenzaldehyde its reactivity is lower than the benzaldehyde. In the case of trans-cinnamaldehyde, the CC bond is existed between aromatic ring and the carbonyl group. In general, the order of inductive effect is as follows: −OR >−CC−>−H. It is a known fact that the trans-cinnamaldehyde is more stable than benzaldehyde and 4-methoxybenzaldehyde because of inductive effect. It is interesting to note in the case of aldehydes that the acetal formation selectivity is higher than 90% irrespective of the nature of the aldehyde [63]. However, in the case of ketones (Table 1, entry 7 and 8), the conversion was lower than aldehydes (65 and 12% respectively). Although the catalytic reaction conditions were same, the conversion of ketones was decreased. As known, ketones are more stable compounds than aldehydes hence the conversion of aldehydes was higher than the conversion of ketones. However, the acetal formation selectivity is higher than 90% with both aldehydes and ketones. There results demonstrate that the M-POP is a highly promising catalyst for selective acetalization of carbonyl compounds. In Table 2 , the results of acetalization of carbonyl compounds with ethylene glycol (EG) are listed. The substrates used in this investigation were benzaldehyde, 4-methoxybenzaldehyde, and trans-cinnamaldehyde respectively. The acetalization of aldehydes with EG showed similar results with that of methanol as presented in Table 1. In other words, the conversion of aldehyde and the selectivity of acetal formation with EG is almost similar to that of acetalization of aldehyde with MeOH. However, the acetalization reaction time was much longer than 2h (12 and 24h). It was observed that the conversion of aldehydes and the selectivity of acetal formation were not increased rapidly. However, the final results were almost similar with varying reaction times. The catalytic results clearly indicated that the acetalization of carbonyl compounds could be achieved in short reaction times with M-POP as the promising catalyst. It was also noted from this study that M-POP could be utilized for acetalization reaction with many kinds of carbonyl compounds and alcohols with varying reaction times. It should be pointed out here that the acetylazation was carried out at a much lower temperature of 40°C and reasonably good results were obtained within 2h. Catalyst recyclability test For ascertaining the recyclability of the catalyst, the M-POP catalyst was recovered and reused after conducting the acetalization reaction. After the reaction, the catalyst was recovered by filtration and washed with DCM, excess distilled water, and acetone multiple times. The washed catalyst was dried under vacuum at 200°C for 12h. Thus dried M-POP catalyst was directly utilized in the acetalization reaction once again. Repeated acetalization reaction experiments were conducted with benzaldehyde and MeOH at 40°C for 2h. The recyclability tests were conducted more than 3 times with the same catalyst. It was observed from these experiments that there is no big change in the M-POP ability for acetalization reaction as shown in Table 3 . The conversion of benzaldehyde was almost 89% and the acetal product selectivity was 98% in the 3rd cycle. As can be noted from Table 1 (entry 2), the conversion of benzaldehyde was not decreased substantially and the selectivity of acetal formation was almost same after 3rd recycle of the catalyst. These results confirm the usefulness of M-POP catalyst for large scale application of acetalization in the industrial organic synthesis. Further work is under active progress on those lines. H-bonding motif in acetalization reaction As mentioned in the earlier paragraphs, the H-bonding motif for catalytic reactions can solve some of the disadvantages of acid catalysts [21]. The M-POP is a high nitrogen content material which can be explored for H-bonding catalysis. The triazine’s nitrogen and the secondary amine can form H-bond with carbonyl group (−CHO) and hydroxyl group (−OH). To estimate the H-bonding energy of carbonyl compounds and alcohol with M-POP, the DFT calculations were utilized. From DFT calculations, it was found that there are three kinds of H-bonds possible between MeOH and the catalyst. One H-bond is between secondary amine’s nitrogen and the hydroxyl group’s hydrogen. This H-bond’s binding energy was calculated to be −0.008kcalmol−1 (Fig. S5a). Another H-bond is between secondary amine’s hydrogen and the hydroxyl group’s oxygen. The corresponding H-bond binding energy was found to be −0.3kcalmol−1 (Fig. S5b). The other H-bond is between triazine’s nitrogen and the hydroxyl group. This binding energy was found to be −4.7kcalmol−1 (Fig. S5c). This H-bond is strongest and it is expected that H-bond of M-POP and MeOH is preferred to triazine’s nitrogen and hydroxyl group’s hydrogen. In the case of benzaldehyde and M-POP, it is possible to have one H-bond between benzaldehyde and the M-POP. The typical H-bond with binding energy between benzaldehyde and M-POP is shown in Fig. S6. From the DFT calculations, one could propose the catalytic mechanism of acetalization reaction over M-POP as shown in Fig. 4 . The benzaldehyde can form H-bond with secondary amine, and MeOH can form H-bond with secondary amine and triazine’s nitrogen. To demonstrate H-bonding effect with M-POP and the reagent, the 1H solid state MAS NMR analysis was utilized (SI). Such analyses were already exploited by various researcher groups in the literature [64], especially in the bio-macromolecules research area [65]. The solid state NMR measurements supported in favour of the mechanism as shown in Fig. 4 in line with literature [63,64]. However, further studies are necessary in order to endorse the proposed mechanism. Nevertheless, M-POP exhibited good catalytic activity for acetalization of various carbonyl compounds with methanol or ethylene glycol under mild conditions which is a good evidence for its catalytic action. Conclusions The micro- and mesoporous hierarchical melamine-based porous organic polymer (M-POP) was successfully synthesized by microwave-assisted method with a high specific surface area and pore volume. Without the use of solvents, the acetalization of various carbonyl compounds with methanol or ethylene glycol was carried out by employing M-POP. The M-POP showed superior catalytic performance in terms of conversion and product selectivity. From DFT calculations and proton solid state NMR technique, the involvement of H-bonding in the mechanism of acetalization reaction over M-POP is addressed. It is demonstrated that M-POP can be utilized as a metal-free catalyst for acetalization of various carbonyl compounds under mild conditions. The M-POP is an ecofriendly catalyst because it is metal-free and recyclable. Acknowledgements The authors thank Inha University for the Research Grant [56993] to carryout this work. BMR thanks Korea Federation of Science and Technology (KOFST) for the offer of an Invitation Scientist position under the Brain Pool program. coredata.dc:description: An efficient melamine-porous organic polymer (M-POP) as N-functionalized organic polymer catalyst was synthesized with melamine and terephthalaldehyde by a facile microwave-assisted method. The synthesized M-POP exhibited a high specific surface area with hierarchical pore structure of both mesoporosity and microporosity. The rich N-moieties namely, CN and NH from the melamine precursor were found to show hydrogen-bonding ability with various organic molecules such as carbonyl compounds. This was illustrated in the acetalization of aldehydes and ketones with methanol or ethylene glycol under mild conditions as a metal-free H-bonding catalyst with high product selectivity. The superior catalytic performance of M-POP was attributed to the availability of a large number of H-bonding sites both as H-donor and H-acceptor between the reactants and the catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Hierarchical porous organic polymer as an efficient metal-free catalyst for acetalization of carbonyl compounds with alcohols
